took him to - for the tournament and set an early marker.Then, Wiesberger and Hebert traded the lead over the afternoon in what was a preview of the play-off.Wiesberger edged into the lead with two holes to go but a bogey on the th saw him drop back to -.Frenchman Hebert, who secured a spot at The Open through his performance in East Lothian, had already wrapped up his fourth round by that point and had the advantage of being able to sit back and watch how the other players handled the pressure.His final round  ndash a score matched by Johnston ndash gave him a good chance of winning the title.In the end, all eyes were on the par four th hole, with Wiesberger needing par to force a play-off.He took his time over the vital putt, which he sank to ensure the drama would continue.Seventy-two holes could not decide an outright winner, which meant the need to play the th hole again.In the first play-off, it looked like advantage Hebert after a fine second shot but Wiesberger secured par.Hebert had a putt to take the title but could not do it and had to settle for a par of his own to force a second play-off hole.The Frenchman had a second opportunity but again it was not to be and both men made their journey back to the th tee for a third play-off hole.Finally, Wiesberger wrapped up the victory in the fading light.Elsewhere, North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest finished on an impressive - earlier in the day.A final round of  saw him pick up six birdies over the course with two bogeys along the way.The score was good enough for a tie of rd, one position behind last yearrsquos winner Brandon Stone and Rory McIlroy.He was East Lothianrsquos last representative, with David Drysdale cut after the third round yesterday .The former Dunbar Grammar School pupil scored  in his third round, which saw him finish the tournament on - alongside Englandrsquos Ashley Chesters.

title: coastguard-called-dinghy-runs-aground
story: The volunteer teams were called out at about .pm after off-duty coastguard and RNLI personnel spotted the wooden dinghy near Dunbarrsquos swimming pool.Crew from the townrsquos RNLI in-shore leboat came ashore to the dinghy and found no signs of recent occupancy.It was then taken under tow back to the nearby harbour.A spokesman for Dunbar Coastguard, who were joined at the scene by colleagues from North Berwick, said: ldquoThe name lsquoTommy rsquo is written on the side of the dinghy and efforts by the Coastguard to trace the owners have so far been unsuccessful.ldquoIf you recognise the dinghy or know of a vessel named lsquoTommy rsquo, please contact the Aberdeen Coastguard Operations Centreon   quoting incident number .ldquoIf you see someone in dficulty or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, beaches, clfs, mud or water, call  immediately and ask for the Coastguard.

title: haddingtons-swimming-pool-re-open-earlier-expected
story: The facilities have been undergoing a refurbishment and had initially been expected to re-open at the end of June, but that was later pushed back to next Saturday .However, it has now been announced that the pool will now re-open on Monday at am.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which runs the centre on behalf of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoThese works will completely enhance the visitor experience for all customers and have transformed the pool into a bright and modern community asset which can only benefit the population of Haddington and beyond.Tom Reid, East Lothian Councils head of infrastructure, added: ldquoThis is an excellent example of partnership working and we are delighted with the outcome, which we know will be greatly appreciated by both customers and staff alike.

title: metal-detecting-fan-hailed-hero-finding-wedding-ring-fell-sea
story: Toby Binnian, from Newbyth ndash between Tyninghame and Whitekirk ndash and Holly Clement got married on Saturday.But the ringplunged into the waters off Tyninghame during a swim the very next day.Devastated, Holly sent a social media SOS to Dean Houston after she discovered the existence of East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.And when Dean kindly agreed to sweep the wet sand at Tyninghame on Monday morning with his metal detector when the tide was out, he surprised even himself when he found what he described as a ldquoneedle in a haystack.Holly, who grew up in Haddington, said it had been an eventful start to married le but they were delighted to once again be in possession of the cherished band.She said: ldquoToby was so upset that he lost it and it is more relief for him than anything ."Friends and family were devastated for him and we are just so happy to get the ring back.PE teacher Toby, , and dentist Holly, , first met while at school at Edinburgh Academy and have been together for  years.They were married at the Log Cabin at Ravensheugh on Saturday and decided to mark their first full day as husband and we with a swim at nearby Tyninghame.Holly recalled: ldquoAll our friends arrived and we were on the beach going to go for a swim."We debated about whether to keep the ring on or off and we thought because it was quite a snug fit that it would be fine.ldquoToby went out for a swim while we were jumping through the waves.ldquoI donrsquot know what possessed him but someone asked himthe ring was OK and he tested it to see whether it would go over his knuckle.ldquoThen, all of a sudden, it went plop into the water and he was panicking.ldquoIt is a palladium ring and not a very bright white colour, so it disappeared into the murky waters and we were chest high in the water.Amongst the panic, the couple, who now live in York, decided to bring in outside help.A search of Facebook brought up the newly-formed East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.Holly said: ldquoWe just said: lsquoPlease help, my idiot new husband has dropped his ring in the sea.rsquoShe remained ldquoblindly optimistic of being reunited with the ring because they had a rough idea where it had fallen into the water.Within an hour, the group got in touch and, after a check of tide times, arrived at the beach on Monday morning.Holly said: ldquoI had slightly given up hope and walked up to sit with family on the headland and stay out of the way.ldquoI just heard lots of cheering and we all sprinted down to check it was real.Dean, from the local metal detecting club, was delighted to be able to help and within an hour had tracked down the ring in the wet sand.The Dunbar resident thought it would be like finding ldquoa needle in a haystack and added: ldquoI was expecting an area of a couple of feet by a couple of feet but it was more like  or  feet square that they gave me.Dean was given a helping hand by his black Labrador Roxy.He said: ldquoMy dog was digging holes and I just walked over and the metal detector beeped.ldquoThey all started running up and giving me hugs, which is a bit embarrassing when you donrsquot know them!ldquoThen they were all trying to phone Toby.Holly said she was forever thankful to Dean, adding: ldquoHe was just so lovely, unassuming and he was just great.ldquoToby is a little bit scared and does not know whether to keep the ring on or take it off!ldquoHe is wearing it just now but he is thinking about getting it resized.Anyone interested in finding out more about the metal detecting club should email elmdclub@yahoo or search for East Lothian Metal Detecting Club on Facebook.

title: east-lothian-surfer-features-new-advert-carling
story: The five surfers ndash aged between  and  ndash took on the waves for a national advertising campaign for the beer giant called lsquoMade Localrsquo.Retired roofer Ian McKay, from Whitekirk, was joined by Jason Burnett, Douglas Brown and Dee Ripol, all from Edinburgh, with filming taking place over two days nearly two years ago. Rod Wallace was also present.A film crew set up base for the advert, which can be viewed online, at Pease Bay, about two miles from the East Lothian county boundary, with impressive surfing conditions helping to create a stunning advert.Jason, , told the Courier: ldquoWe were approached by Carling, who found us through social media.ldquoThey were impressed by how wersquore making it where wersquore from ndash my surfboard-making business for the local community in particular struck a chord. Our story inspired Carling to feature us in its Made Local advert with the aim of encouraging more people to follow their passions in their local area.ldquoThe Made Local Fund is Carlingrsquos multi-million-pound commitment over the next three years to those things that matter most to local communities, just like us and our surfing.ldquoCarling have recently supported me in providing funding for the materials needed to hand craft and design some surfboards which will be donated to the Scottish Surfing Federation.ldquoThese bespoke surfboards will be provided free to people who want to try surfing for the first time.Ian, , has been surfing with friends for more than  years, with the sport gaining popularity across Scotland.And while surfing hot spots include Hawaii, Calornia and Australiarsquos Gold Coast, East Lothian was proving popular as well.Jason, who makes surfboards, said the county was an ideal place for them to get into the water.He said: ldquoCold water surfing in East Lothian is hardcore!ldquoIn winter the waves are big, the weather is cold and the sea is colder, but we donrsquot let that put us off ndash we donrsquot care how cold it is.ldquoWersquore proud to surf in all weathers and all year round. Nothing stops us.ldquoSurfing these waters is also a big social thing for us too.ldquoThe friendships we have forged through years of surfing in these freezing cold waters still stand strong today.ldquoWe have surfed all over the world, but no matter where the sport has taken us, coming back to home waters is where our hearts lie.ldquoThe local beaches along the East Lothian coastline are really special and have some of the most stunning scenery in the world.The video can be viewed by going to Carlingrsquos YouTube page.

title: scottish-open-renaissance-club-attracts-record-attendance
story: Nearly , people attended the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open while the competition, which was played at The Renaissance Club, also produced its lowest score to par.Bernd Wiesberger was crowned the winner following three play-off holes at the course, near Dirleton.He carded  under ndash which was matched by Benjamin Hebert and was the lowest score to par since the competition began in .Early figures suggest , attended the competition, up by nearly , from last yearrsquos tournament at Gullane Golf Club.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said that the tournament had proven ldquoa great success, with analysis to be carried out to look at its economic benefits.She said: ldquoThe Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open was a great success, with record attendance figures of almost , who enjoyed world-class golf at The Renaissance Club.ldquoThe economic boost to East Lothian of this tournament and the forthcoming Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open will be independently assessed and we look forward to seeing the results of that assessment later this year.ldquoIt was also a successful event for the many local food and drink suppliers who won contracts to supply the event.Neil Christison, VisitScotland regional director, felt the eventrsquos success was another great advert for the county as a golfing destination.He said: ldquoThe Scottish Open at The Renaissance Club was a great success, attracting visitors from across the world and showcasing East Lothian as a top destination for international events to a global audience.ldquoAnd there is still more to come for East Lothian this summer, with Ladies Scottish Open and Scottish Senior Open taking place in the region in the coming weeks.ldquoThe staging of these high-profile sporting events has an immense impact on tourism in East Lothian and surrounding areas, attracting golf fans from across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWith its range of  courses, high-quality accommodation, food and drink, and visitor attractions, East Lothian really does live up to its name as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast.ldquoGolf is a vital part of the visitor economy, with the ripple effect felt in shops, hotels, restaurants and a wide iety of other businesses across the region.ldquoGolf tourism is worth poundm to the country annually ndash and around pound.million to East Lothian alone.Cast a great lightGael Pollitt, chair of Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, felt that the event had cast the county in a great light.He said: ldquoThere is no doubt that the hosting of the ASI Scottish Open on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast again showed East Lothian to be a golfing Mecca and the live TV streaming of the championship throughout the world will surely boost interest in all the county has to offer.ldquoDuring commentary and written reports there were frequent references made to the wide range of golf courses and the ersity of accommodation options available.ldquoOn our stand in the championship village, it was very encouraging to hear the comments from visitors who had travelled considerable distances of their desire toand play courses that they had not previously appreciated, as well as visit the many other tourist attractions in East Lothian.ldquoIn three weeksrsquo time, it is the turn of the ladies to compete on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, when again many of the top players in the world will be present.North Berwick Coastal ward councillors Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay also felt the event had gone well.Mr Goodfellow said: ldquoThe Scottish Open has been another success for East Lothian tourism and has brought positive worldwide exposure for the county and economic benefit for local businesses.ldquoWe were lucky with the weather and the use of The Renaissance course minimising local traffic disruption.ldquoThe credit for the smooth running of the event must go to our council officers and the event organisers.Mr Findlay added: ldquoIt was a great event for East Lothian and showcases Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, which is now the premier golfing location in Scotland.Councillor Jane Henderson, a ward colleague, agreed that the event appeared to have gone smoothly but she questioned what impact it had had on local businesses over the four days.The councillor noted that a number of businesses were very quiet during the tournament but acknowledged that the success of the competition could leave a positive long-term impact.She said: ldquoYou have to look at both sides and that is definitely my stance.ldquoIn the shorter term, people have bills and rent to pay and are running businesses.ldquoIt is alright for tourism and economic development to say the long-term impact will pay off in East Lothian.Businesses painted a mixed picture when it came to the impact of the tournament.Chris Hansen, owner of The Open Arms in Dirleton, was among those enjoying a fruitful week.He said: ldquoIt was a good week. The place was maybe a little bit quieter during the day when it was centred on the golf course.ldquoIn general, we were quite lucky with the weather.Gullanersquos Co-op store was also affected by the tournament, with traffic encouraged to avoid the village.Greg Millar, store manager, said: ldquoWe actually did better than what I thought we would but didnrsquot do as well as the business thought we would,that makes sense.ldquoIt could have been a lot betterthe traffic was erted through Gullane.Meanwhile, Tricia Johnstone, of Fenton Barns Farm Shop and Cafe, felt the event had a detrimental impact on their business.She said: ldquoIt damages business more than increases it.ldquoA lot of people just stay away.But Carol Millar, from The Golfers Rest on North Berwick High Street, said the pub was ldquobusy, adding: ldquoOn Friday and Saturday it was absolutely crazy. I donrsquot knowit is because we are called The Golfers Rest but it was quite busy.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, which also covers Dirleton, said the impact in terms of flow of people and traffic through the village was ldquonot very signicant.He said: ldquoI went on Saturday and Sunday and there was a wonderful atmosphere. I think it was a very good thing for the area.ldquoI think it would be fair to say it did not have a major impact on the village of Dirleton itself but, speaking as a community council for the other areas, it was a big event for us and brought a tremendous number of visitors to the area and I think that has a long-term legacy.

title: provost-flies-flag-east-lothian-festival-france
story: John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, was carrying the Haddington flag through Aubigny-sur-Nere on Sunday afternoon during a parade in the Franco-Scottish Festival.The Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor was flanked by his son Douglas and brother Jim, who were carrying the town keys.Mr McMillan is visiting the town on a family holiday and was joined there by Haddington Pipe Band.He the Courier: ldquoIt was quite a long parade and I thought I really should be flying the flag.ldquoEverybody in the pipe band played tremendously over the weekend.ldquoI am here on holiday but was asked to open the festival and the flag was here.ldquoI had been given the keys to the town on Friday evening at a formal ceremony and it was a real honour to march behind the pipe band as they were leading the parade.Liz McDougall, the pipe band quartermaster, carried the flag at the morning ceremony at the war memorial alongside the townrsquos veterans.A copy of last weekrsquos Courier ndash wrapped in tartan and red, white and blue ribbon ndash was also presented to the townrsquos archive.A link between the East Lothian town and Aubigny, which is between Orleans and Bourges in central France, dates back to .Residents of each town have regularly made the trip to their counterparts.The twinning links are evident throughout Haddington, with a sign outside Haddington Corn Exchange bearing the street name Place drsquoAubigny, and the townrsquos leisure centre also named after the French settlement.Mr McMillan explained the importance of the relationship between the two countries and the two towns.He said: ldquoI think the French are aware of the Auld Alliance but in Aubigny it is particularly alive and remembered with links to the Hundred Yearsrsquo War, when a Scottish lord rescued the town from the English and gave wood to rebuild the town.

title: bid-name-new-sports-pavilion-39-unofficial-mayor-north-berwick-39
story: Labour Party stalwart and former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian FC Pilmar Smith passed away in November last year.Now, plans are being drawn up to pay tribute to Mr Smith, who was , including the idea of a plaque in his honour at a new sports pavilion.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, who represents North Berwick, said: ldquoThere has been a move within the town to have some sort of commemorative something around the town.ldquoThe proposal at the moment is that there is a new sports pitch being built up at the new housing by the high school.ldquoThere is to be a pavilion there and the proposal is we name it the Pilmar Smith Pavilion and a plaque goes up to that effect.ldquoIt would probably mention his connections with football over the years and North Berwick.The pitch, which is to the west of Law Primary School, is not yet playable, with the new surface needing time to bed in..However, it is expected to open later this year, with planning permission already in place for the pavilion.East Lothian Council is looking to appoint a contractor for the pavilion, with work expected to start in November and be complete by spring next year.Mr Smith was raised in Edinburgh and spent several decades as a bookmaker.A Hearts fan all his le, he became vice-chairman of the Tynecastle club in , during which time they twice finished as runners-up in the Scottish Football League Premier Division.He held the position for  years before stepping down following a change of ownership.Mr Smith was chairman of East Lothian Constituency Labour Party until about  and spent more than a decade as chairman of Lothian Buses.Mr Goodfellow previously expressed his gratitude to Mr Smith in helping him to be elected as the first-ever Labour councillor for the area.He said: ldquoIt would be an excellent tribute to someone who contributed a lot to North Berwick during his time here.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, gave her backing to the idea.She told the Courier: ldquoThe community council were very saddened to hear of the passing of Pilmar Smith in November last year.ldquoPilmar had lived in North Berwick for around  years and was as well-known as he was well loved.ldquoOne can only imagine how long it took Pilmar to walk from one end of High Street to the other when you consider that almost every person he passed would stop him for a lsquoquick chatrsquo!ldquoFollowing requests from residents, the community council agreed that something was required to commemorate Pilmar and local elected councillor Jim Goodfellow suggested that the new football pavilion might be the ideal site.ldquoGiven that Pilmar was a lelong fan of Hearts Football Club, where he also served as a director and vice-chairman for more than a decade, this seemed a fitting tribute.ldquoThe community council have since allocated funding to purchase a plaque and, with great fondness, look forward to naming the new football pavilion the lsquoPilmar Smith Pavilionrsquo in his memory.

title: tranent-minister-rubs-shoulders-royalty-garden-party-palace-holyroodhouse
story: The Rev Erica Wishart, minister at Tranent Parish Church, was thrilled to be invited to the royal garden party in Edinburgh this year after being nominated by Michael Williams, Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.She said: ldquoIt was a real privilege to be there, in the presence of Her Majesty the Queen along with Prince Andrew, Prince Edward and Princess Anne. My husband, the Rev Bill Wishart [minister at St Martinrsquos Parish Church in the Magdalene area of Edinburgh], came with me as my lsquoplus onersquo and we had a lovely afternoon walking around the gardens of Holyroodhouse in the sunshine.ldquoWe couldnrsquot get near enough to see the royal family close up, but we did manage to photograph the Queen from afar as she paused on the steps for the national anthem it was easy to spot her as she was wearing a bright salmon pink coat and hat.The royal family hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at the Palace of Holyroodhouse ndash with more than , people attending in total. They are designed to recognise and reward the public service of the attendees.Erica added: ldquoThere were a few bands playing music in dferent parts of the gardens, which added atmosphere to the event.ldquoWe enjoyed the tea, sandwiches and cakes in the tea tent: I had been told to expect tiny ones but actually they were a decent size.There were cucumber sandwiches ndash of course! ndash and the egg sandwiches had mint leaves in them which gave an unusual taste, quite refreshing. We also had fruit tarts, Victoria sponge and macaroons, all very tasty.ldquoYou couldnrsquot miss the royal tea tent ndash it was the one with the crown on top ndash but we couldnrsquot get near it, the crowds were so big.ldquoIt was fun wandering around seeing all the dferent outfits, unorms and hats. Someone asked uswe had met anyone of note and I replied: lsquoYes, Billrsquos aunty Isabelle and her pal Dot!rsquo They were the first familiar faces we saw in the crowd.ldquoThatrsquos one of the good things about the garden party: people of all ages, from all walks of le are invited, so therersquos a feeling of inclusivity.ldquoIt was a grand day out and I have written to the Lord Lieutenant to thank him for nominating me to attend on behalf of Tranent Parish Church.

title: jennifer-maciver-positive-pathway-parenthood
story: For some, surrogacy ndashwhen a woman carries and gives birth to a baby for another person or couple ndashis the only option.The number of people applying to the courts to be formally recognised as the parents of a child following a surrogacy arrangement has increased across the UK in recent years reflecting a welcome change in societyrsquos views on the lsquotraditionalrsquo family.Jenner Maciver, head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew welcomes a review of the existing legal framework around surrogacy.ldquoItrsquos very much a live and current issue and we are pleased to see the Scottish Law Commission and Law Commission of England and Wales have been jointly appraising existing legislation and have published proposals for consultation. The current law around surrogacy is outdated and doesnrsquot reflect modern medical advances or changes in social attitudes. Surrogacy is a particularly sensitive and emotionally demanding process for everyone involved so we welcome anything which simplies or modernises the legislation. A draft report is anticipated, followed by draft legislation by  but their proposals offer a clear indication about the recommended direction of travel, she says.Parental ordersCurrently, the surrogate, and her spouse ndash she has one ndash are the legal parents of the child at birth and their names are noted on the birth certicate. The intended parents must make an application to the court for a parental order to be recognised as the childrsquos parents, with the legal rights and responsibilities this entails. This can take around six months to process which she points out can pose several potential problems. The first is that while the intended parents are socially and psychologically the parents, that doesnrsquot match the legal position, which can cause identity problems. On the flip side, the surrogate doesnrsquot normally view herself as the childrsquos mother, but the law does. Secondly,the child needs medical care during the first six months of their le the intended parents will likely not have any legal standing to take medical decisions about the young child in their care, which is not on any view a good situation for the child.ldquoAt the moment there is a considerable gap between peoplersquos expectations and the law and signicant potential for misunderstandings. This is not a positive environment in which to welcome a child and we are pleased to see this being tackled as part of the review, says Maciver.She explains that the Law Commissionsrsquo lsquonew pathwayrsquo will have several positive outcomes: it will allow intended parents to become the legal parents from birth in some cases remove of the need for a genetic link between the intended parents and the child in some cases establish a new regulator for surrogacy create a register to allow those born of surrogacy arrangements to access information and for international surrogacy arrangements help those who have a child abroad to bring their child back to the UK with less red tape.The new framework, she says will set out proactive measures including ndashintroducing pre-conception safeguards that are built in before the baby is conceived to help to avoid problems later in the process. ldquoThe proposal is that before the child is conceived there must be a written agreement between the surrogate and the parent, an independent assessment of the childrsquos welfare, the intended parents and the surrogate are all bound to take independent legal advice so that they understand the process, they are all medically screened and criminal checks are carried out, she explains.The intended parents and the surrogate are also required to go to implications counselling to help establish the foundation for an appropriate and positive relationship.Which all sounds like an onerous process ndashbut itrsquos one which Maciver believes will actually signicantly enhance the current situation. ldquoItrsquos more proactive and sees the introduction of meaningful safeguards ndashwhich will hopefully reduce the problems that can sometimes arise after the birth of a child and provide clarity for those entering into a surrogacy arrangement exactly whatrsquos expected of them.The overseas optionOwing to the restrictions on commercial surrogacy in the UK and the dficulty in finding willing surrogates some people choose to go to countries where commercial surrogacy is legally possible ndashwhich often leads to further complications when trying to bring the baby back to the UK.Overseas situations, she says, account for approximately half of surrogacies and they will still have to apply for a parental order, which is also getting an overhaul. For example, currently the intended parents have to apply for that within six months of the child being born, which is a relatively narrow window. The proposal is remove that time limit. They are also proposing changes to make it easier and quicker to get a passport or visa to bring the child to live with them in Scotland. Unlike other areas of family law in Scotland, , surrogacy is an area that has seen cultural attitudes change faster than legislation and Maciver believes that the Law Commissionsrsquo proposals are welcome, though not perfect.While commercial surrogacy is banned, reasonable payments are allowed, which leads to grey areas which the proposals donrsquot yet address, for example, what is reasonable and what strays into lsquopaymentrsquo ldquoThe law in this instance is very dficult to apply, says Maciver. If the payment is higher than reasonably anticipated what options does the court have  There has so far been no refusal of a parental order based on the level of payment but itrsquos probably the most contentious area in the consultation. Itrsquos one in which people hold strong opposing views and so the Law Commissions have canvassed opinion about how these limitations should be set and enforced.Single parentsIn the meantime, though she is encouraged by the fact that in January the law was changed following a challenge to the Human Rights Act  meaning that single parents can now apply for a parental order. ldquoThis was the single most urgent issue: previously only married couples, civil partners, cohabitants or people in other enduring relationships could apply.And the future  Maciver says that there are dfering views about the best route forward ndashand of course the proposed changes are still at consultation stage. But she believes that the new pathwayis long overdue and will have very positive effect, improving the way that surrogacy works and better protecting the interests of surrogates, intended parents and ultimately the children involved.Which is a community whose numbers are fast increasing.Jenner Maciver, is head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew, whocombine specialist, practical advice with a responsive, supportive and discrete service.For more information abour how Gillespie Macandrew can help please visitwww.gillespiemacandrew

title: first-look-haddingtons-newly-refurbished-swimming-pool
story: Work got under way at the pool and health suite within the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre in April and ndash after a delay ndash the pool is due to re-open on Monday.Essential maintenance and interior deacutecor works have been carried out at the sports centre, off Mill Wynd, over several weeks.During the work, the two pools were drained, with a new light, bright ceiling covering the outdated wood cladding.New lighting has also been installed while the locker rooms have also been given a facelt and tiles have been given a thorough clean.The new-look pool was revealed to enjoyleisure members and politicians on Friday afternoon.The facility is one of East Lothianrsquos original sports centres and originally opened its doors as Haddington Swimming Pool in September .The much-loved site consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Before the temporary closure, the facility welcomed about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, swimming club training, school and public use.

title: tesco-raises-prices-1-000-products-two-weeks
story: The supermarket, which has said cutting prices to compete with discounters Aldi and Lidl is a key priority, put up prices by % on average during the first two weeks of July.:Tesco reveals bumper profits after turnaroundA five-pack of bananas has gone up % from p to pound own brand farfalle, macaroni and linguine pasta have all risen % from p a pack to p seedless strawberry jam is up % to p and iceberg lettuces are up % at p each.The highest price rise was for Merchant Gourmet puy lentils, up from pound. to pound. a pack ndash a rise of %.Industry sources said prices will go up and down across the whole industry but the size and scale of Tescorsquos recent rises were notably high.Supermarkets typically move prices on branded products due to promotions coming to an end, but prices on own-brand food and drink tend to be more stable.Out of the top  price rises for the supermarket,  were own-brand products.The branded items with the biggest rises include Cathedral City Mild Cheddar up % to pound. for  grams -packs of Carlsberg lager up % from pound to pound Ferrero Rocher chocolates up from pound to pound. and a kg bag of Salaam basmati rice now pound versus pound previously ndash a rise of %.The data, which is used internally by grocers to monitor the industry, is provided by Brand View.:Tesco staff hit by redundancy payment errorsTesco said the rises were due to cost pressures that were hitting the entire market, and pointed out that over the last three weeks prices were cut on  items by % on average, including own-brand coconut milk, down p to p, andTesco frosted flakes cereal, down p to pound.A spokesman said: ldquoOver recent months, cost pressures have continued to build and impact the market.ldquoWersquove worked hard to offset these pressures, and focused on protecting our customers for as long as possible. But, like the wider market, we have had to reflect these pressures in the price of some products.ldquoFor the majority of products that have increased in price over the last three weeks, we still beat or match the cheapest of the Big Four [Tesco, Sainsburyrsquos, Asda and Morrisons].Price has been a major factor on the high street in recent years, driven by the rise and rise of discount supermarkets Aldi and Lidl.Tesco has made its own attempts to move into the discount sector, launching its own discount supermarketJackrsquos.Clive Black, retail analyst at Shore Capital, said: ldquoThe key journey that the UK supermarkets are on is to narrow the basket with the German discounters, who also move prices up and down. That is a key axis that shoppers undoubtedly notice.

title: british-tanker-stena-impero-39-seized-iran-39
story: The Stena Impero and Liberian MV Mesdar were both captured in the Strait of Horduz, in the Persian Gulf, and boarded by armed guards.The Mesdar was later released and allowed to continue its voyage, with all crew said to be ldquosafe and well. It is unclear what the status of the Stena Impero is, however.The crisis emerged after the Iranian Revolutionary Guard told state TV they had seized the Stena Impero oil vessel after it strayed into Iranian waters in the Strait of Hormuz.It comes after the UK seized the Iranian tanker, Grace , off the course of Gibraltar on July .It was suspected of carrying oil bound for Syria, in breach of EU sanctions. The apparent tit-for-tat retaliation by Iran yesterday is being seen as a way of forcing adeal with the UK for theof Grace .Iranrsquos semi-official news agency, Fars, said the Stena Impero had been ldquoviolating international maritime rules.However, the tankerrsquos owner Stena Bulk have disputed this. It said the tanker was in international waters at the time.Mr Hunt said there were no British citizens on either vessel, and described the seizure as ldquounacceptable.He added: ldquoIt is essential that freedom of navigation is maintained and that all ships can move safely and freely in the region.It is believed the Stena Impero was captured around .pm local time . The Stena Impero was en route between Kandla in western India and the Port of Jubail in Saudi Arabia at the time of being seized. In a statement, Stena Bulk said ship manager ndash Clydebank-based Northern Marine Management ndash had lost contact with the crew of  after ldquounidentied small crafts and a helicopter approached the vessel.The company added: ldquoThere are  seafarers aboard. There have been no reported injuries and their safety is of primary concern to both owners and managers.ldquoThe priority of both vessel owner Stena Bulk and ship manager Northern Marine Management is the safety and welfare of the crew.ldquoWe are in close contact with UK government authorities.The operator of the Mesdar tanker, Glasgow-based Norbulk Shipping UK, said communication had been re-established with the ship after it was boarded by armed guards at around .pm on Friday.In statement last night, it said: ldquoCommunication has been re-established with the vessel and Master confirmed that the armed guards have left and the vessel is free to continue the voyage. All crew are safe and well.A spokeswoman from the UKrsquos Ministry of Defence said: ldquoWe are urgently seeking further information and assessing the situation.It comes after a war of words broke out between the US and Iran over the fate of an unmanned drone. President Donald Trump said the USS Boxer had shot down a drone belonging to Iran on Thursday after it came within , yards of the American warship and ignored repeated warnings to back off. However, Iran later denied that the drone belonged to Iran.: US warship shoots down hostile and provocative US droneA spokeswoman from the UKs Ministry of Defence said: "We are urgently seeking further information and assessing the situation following reports of an incident in the Gulf."Labour deputy leader Tom Watson tweeted that the situation was "amatter of real concern"  Any move to seize a British tanker would be a signicant and harmful escalation of a situation where de-escalation is needed.: British woman in Iran spy row admitted to psychiatric wardIt comes after a war of words broke out between the US and Iran in the past  hours over the fate of an unmanned drone.President Donald Trump told a White House press conference on Thursday that the USS Boxer had shot down a drone belonging to Iran after it came within  yards of the American warship and ignored repeated warnings to back off.However, Iran later denied that the drone belonged to Iran and suggested the US had shot down one of its own drones by mistake.

title: astronaut-doug-wheelock-shares-apollo-insights
story: People across the globe watched in amazement asNeilArmstrong andBuzzAldrin walked across the lunarlandscape into the early hours of July , taking photos, collecting samples, planting a US flag and taking a call from then-president Richard Nixon.ldquoThatrsquos one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind, Armstrong famously said.Now, as the world turns its eyes to the heavens to mark the thanniversary of the Lunar Landing, an astronaut who followed the Apollo  crewrsquos path into outer space hopes that theirlasting legacycan inspire the next generation of spacefarers.The mission saw three astronauts, Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins, launched into space on July, marking one of humanities biggest moments in space exploration.:World prepares to celebrate  years since man walked on moonDoug Wheelock spent  days in orbit aboard the International Space Stationbetween  and - conducting three space walks ndashandalsoflew a mission on the Space Shuttle Discovery.Speaking exclusively toThe Herald, the -year-old, who now works for NASA mission control, said that his memories of watching the moon landings remain as fresh as ever.Doug Wheelock has visited Scotland to speak for NASAMr Wheelock said: ldquoI wasnine-years-old in the summer of , when Apollo  landed on the moon. I remember crowding around our black  white television watching and listening to Walter Cronkite narrate an event that held our collective imagination captive.ldquoIt was impossible to comprehend what an extraordinary moment this was in time. I didnrsquot fully understand what I was watching, butsomehowI knew we would never be the same as a human race.ldquoSuddenly, everything seemed possible. I remember my Dadsayingldquothe sky is no longer the limit. It inspired me to study math and science, and though the dream of being an astronaut seemed way out of reach for me, I was determined to learn how to fly.ldquoI was an ordinary kid from an ordinary place. Walking on themoon, andsoaring into space seemed like things that were reserved for extraordinary people from extraordinary places, not for ordinary kids like me.The Texan said that blasting off and leaving earthrsquos atmosphere was like ldquothe most amazing amusement park ride yoursquove ever been on, both violent and breathtaking.But the experience of being in space lends a unique insight given to few people. The astronaut, who has watched the Northern lights above Scotland fromthe other side to most people, said: ldquoLooking back on our planet from the vantage point of space, is a le-changing experience.ldquoYou begin to see our planet as a fragile blue oasis, in a vast empty sea of darkness. It puts things into perspective.:Will there be another giant leap He added: ldquoYes, there is time to reflect on and appreciate the fragile beauty of our planet Earth. From the vantage point of space, you can see our planet hanging in the balance of space and time.ldquoThere is beautul order, and complete silence from the sanctity of space. It is a visual experience behind all others in my le. It seems so surreal.ldquoYou can see your beautul home, everyone yoursquove ever known, every word ever spoken, all right there on that ldquoblue mote of dust in a sunbeam.But the connection with Mother Earth remains strong ndash and becomes more powerful the longer you are away.MrWheelock said: ldquoThe feeling that was most overpowering for me was the deep longing for the Earth. All the wonderful senses that we enjoy here on our planet, the sound of rain and distant thunder the sound of birds singing the smell of flowers and the sound of wind through the trees, all conspicuously absent in space. And, after a short while, I began to crave these things.ldquoThe simple pleasures of le are missing in space. There is our beautul blue oasis, our home, and Irsquom not there.Today there is increased interest in ingto the Moon, with Nasa aiming to put feet on thelunar surfaceby ,and multinational plans to build a space stationin orbitin the future.Those who have made the journey remain heroes, however, who lit the way for others to follow.:Humanityrsquos love affair with our silver satelliteMrWheelock - whobecame the first US Army Officer to assume command on the International Space Station in  and stopped over in Scotland on his way backhome -said: ldquoI first met Neil Armstrong in August of . I wasnrsquot starstruck, but was nervous, because after all, I was an ordinary kid from an ordinary place, sitting next to an extraordinary person. I was awe inspired.ldquoI wanted to ask him how he felt when he was walking on the moon, because I remember how I felt watching him walk on the moon."The Apollo crew - Armstrong, Aldrin and Michael CollinsMr Wheelock added: ldquoHis reply astounded me, and quite honestly changed the trajectory of my le. Neil Armstrong answered that one of his first thoughts was a point of reflection, and he thought to himself, ldquohow does an ordinary kid from Wapakoneta, Ohio end up standing on the moon ldquoIthought for a moment about his words, and finally realized that we are all just ordinary kids from ordinary places, struggling to prepare our lives to intersect with the extraordinary opportunity.He added: ldquoI think wersquore just beginning to dreamagainand people are excited about things that once seemed impossible.THE heights which Doug Wheelock reached because of the Moon landings are one that fewexperience, but there are others who were also inspired to follow other paths of a more down-to-earth nature because of events  years ago.And thanks to one, NASA now has its own tartan after a talented designer created a plaid to mark the anniversary of the auspicious occasion.Robert Pool, , from Clydebank, approached the American space agency with his design earlier this year, and was amazed when they adopted it almostimmediately.The plaid is made up of red, white and blue threads for the American connection and NASArsquoS badge, and white, brown and black to represent mankind. Each band has six threads to represent the continents, and through them the whole world.It has been added to the registers of tartan as the official thanniversaryplaid, andwas presented to NASA byMrPoolrsquos daughter Chanel andgrandaugherHolly.The tartanMrPool said he was, naturally, ldquoover the moon to have his design accepted.He said: ldquoI grew up reading and watching sciencefiction, andcan remember seeing the Moon landings on TV when I was just .ldquoIt was unreal, and very hard to describe ndash men were walking on another world, and we were seeing it.ldquoThey say Irsquom part of the NASA family now and the tartan is part of the Apollo story, and thatrsquos just amazing.He added: ldquoAnd I was pleased that it was mygranddaughterHolly who handed it over, because it will be her generation which makes the next steps into space and keeps the dream going. Maybe all the way to Mars.Chanel and Holly present the Tartan to Nasa Chief Scientist Jim Green

title: social-media-puts-hebrides-map-help-photo-op-icons
story: A rowing boat, a little shabby and holding a puddle of dirty water, rests on the machair grass, its peeling turquoise paint echoing the crystal-clear blue of the sea.There are fierce red sunsets and golden dawns, crumbling crofts and craggy hills, bikes propped against signposts warning of otters crossing, artfully placed pebbles and We ldquoheart Uist drawn in the damp sand.Scan a few of the many thousands of #Uist and #hebrides images on Instagram and itrsquos easy to believe the sun ndash when itrsquos not rising or setting in ndash is always a brilliant fiery blaze, that all the houses are brooding shells with no roof, windows or occupants, and bikes fitted with giant panniers are the only mode of transport.Soon the Outer Hebridean islands of Uistrsquos picturesque qualities could be even more in evidence, with the launch of the UKrsquos first ldquoInsta-friendly maps designed to help happy snappers find the best spots to snare thumbs-ups, likes, hearts and shares.Two limited-edition maps have been developed by CalMac Ferries and Outer Hebrides Tourism to cater for a growing breed of Insta-tourists seeking the perfect shot to add to their social media feeds.In perhaps a hint to those who may think the islandsrsquo white sands and turquoise waters are always accompanied by a blisteringly hot sun, The maps have been produced in a waterproof fabric and are said to showcase the best on offer for the photography fan keen on boosting follower numbers.Besides a traditional island map layout, including grid reference points and the typical ldquomuseum and ldquoplace of worship symbols, are new Insta-friendly symbols pinpointing where to get that killer social media shot.The maps have been ided into one chart featuring North Uist, including Berneray, Grimsay and Benbecula, and another highlighting picture-perfect spots in South Uist and Eriskay.But while there are some well-known locations ndash the sweeping sandy bay of Traigh lar in North Uist, Rueval, or the highest point of Benbecula and Grimsay Harbour, where tourists can snap away at colourful fishing boats included on the North Uist map ndash there are also a few lesser-known and possibly even odd inclusions.For the Instagrammer bored with breath-taking beach scenery, therersquos a chance to introduce global followers to a giant carving of Hercules ndash the brown bear that once went missing on North Uist ndash or Our Lady of the Isles in South Uist, a towering white statue that was erected in the late s by a local priest concerned about the nearby weapons testing range.And,they really want to show off their impressive insight into Uist culture, they could share a snap of a cairn that honours Giant Macaskill, the Berneray islander who grew up to be the worldrsquos tallest man.Or Rosinish Point in Eriskay which overlooks where the SS Politician sank, taking , cases of whisky with her.According to Kirsten Christiann, whose Uist Photography business runs workshops to help visitors polish up their skills, there is no doubt the area offers myriad photo options for visitors armed with the right camera equipment.ldquoAnyone coming to photograph the wildle is not going to manage it with a smartphone, she says.ldquoItrsquos not always sunny, she adds, instantly crushing the Instagram myth that every Hebridean beach nestles under blue skies.ldquoBut then, we donrsquot get that much rain because of the wind. Even when the skies are dark and the weather isnrsquot great, you can still get amazing pictures.The wildflowers of the machair, the white sandy bays and the birds of prey, among them the short-eared owl which can be seen during daytime gliding across the moorland, offer the best picture opportunities, she adds.At Lochboisdale Hotel in South Uist, owner Calum MacAulay is braced for the flood of Instagram stars tempted to capture the islands for their followers.If they could pop over at the end of summer and stay for winter, hersquod be even happier.ldquoIt would be fantastic for us to have visitors from October onwards, he says.ldquoWe have had photographers visit outside of summer. They have told us the light here at that time of year canrsquot be beaten.One thing hersquos less keen on, however, are Instagram ldquoinfluencers looking for a free stay infor a hashtag mention to their followers. ldquoI donrsquot think so, he says.While the maps are intended to help photographers find their ideal image, in other areas there have been concerns that picture-hungry tourists could be putting the landscape at risk.Stacked pyramids of stones have appeared on a number of Unesco-listed beaches on Orkney, at the Fairy Glen on the Isle of Skye and on Iona. While enthusiasts say the stones are artistic, nature groups have warned against the practice.Others have been criticised for laying out food in an attempt to lure deer, red squirrels and birds of prey for pictures, while some Instagrammers ndash such as American so-called lsquoprofessional huntressrsquo visitor Larysa Switlyk created outrage after sharing images of a ram, goat and stag killed on a trip to Islay.Freelance landscape and travel photographer Ali Horne warns that a balance is required between encouraging visitors and retaining the uniqueness of beauty spots.ldquoTherersquos a tricky balance between promoting places which donrsquot have enough visitors and having too many, he says.ldquoI now avoid Skye in the summertime because the number of people means itrsquos too populated, and Irsquom becoming more conscious of what I am posting on social media, he adds.Andrew Macnair, of CalMac Ferries, says the maps are in response to rising demand. ldquoWhen we developed the idea of the maps, it was with the intention of using them online to help visitors to the island discover all the hidden gems Uist has to offer.ldquoHowever, the enthusiasm that has flooded into the tourism office for the products showed there was a demand to create a physical product.The maps cost pound and proceeds go to help the Royal National Leboat Institution .Robert McKinnon, Chief Executive of Outer Hebrides Tourism, adds: ldquoSocial media has put the islands on the map, with so many Insta-friendly locations on our doorstep.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors to Uist and seeing Instagram feeds fill with snapshots of their adventures on the islands.

title: cleaner-campervan-helps-highland-tourists-go-extra-mile
story: Summer has brought an invasion of campervans and motorhomes to Scotlandrsquos usually open roads, occupying lay-bys, chugging along the NC, taking the Skye Bridge to the Fairy Pools and sprawling across at least two parking berths outside the local Co-op to stock up on supplies of Chardonnay and hand-cooked crisps.Find yourself staring at the back end of one ndash typically loaded with mountain bikes ndash while negotiating one of the countryrsquos narrow roads and you could be in for a long, frustrating journey.Campervan and motorhome sales and hires in Scotland are said to have rocketed in recent years as adventurous tourists seek to explore hard-to-reach areas and take control of where they visit, when and for how long they stay.Such is the demand for them that some campervan dealers are reporting seven-month waiting lists for certain bespoke vehicles.According to the most recent figures from the National Caravan Council,  saw a  per cent rise in the number of motorhomes registered in the UK, with an estimated , on the road at the time.Itrsquos a figure thatrsquos thought to have leapt even higher since then, fuelled by slick marketing for north coast road trip holidays and a new breed of tourist anxious to lower their carbon footprint by avoiding flying in favour of embracing nature on their own doorstep.However, concern is mounting that the trend for hitting the road means some may be inadvertently adding to the environmental crisis and even creating their own green calamity.Earlier this month, alarm over a ldquocampervan epidemic prompted one McGillivray claimed the vans were taking up limited parking spaces in the area and causing hygiene problems, with ldquowild toileting a particular concern.Others have raised worries that story: After an unsettled weekend of showers and thunderstorms, temperatures are set to rise from Monday.If temperatures stay high in the same spots for three consecutive days, the Met Office deems it a heatwave.But before the sunshine, the UK is facing a wet weekend.Heavy thunderstorms are forecast across Northern Ireland and parts of Scotland on Friday evening ndash with a risk of lightning, hail and sudden downpours.A yellow weather warning is in force across the region.Across the south coast there will also be downpours, causing potentially dficult driving conditions, with Sussex and Kent likely to be the hardest hit, the Met Office said.Saturday will be a mix of sunshine and showers, with a band of rain pushing from west to east over the course of the day.It will stay warm, however, with temperatures sitting between Cand C Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said: ldquoSunday will be a little bit drier with a few showers here and there and temperatures again reaching Cto C .ldquoAcross Northern Ireland and western Scotland itrsquos going to be wet and windy later.He continued: ldquoMonday will be wet and windy across northwestern parts of the UK, where there will be one or two showers but temperatures will be rising ndash wersquore looking at highs of C .ldquoOn Tuesday the rain and strong winds in the North West will have eased and it will turn drier, where there should be lots of sunshine with highs of Cor higher.London and the South East have the greatest chance of getting to C , he said.## Hot weather on the wayhellip ##As the heat builds across Europe in the coming days, hot weather will arrive in the UK next week # pic tMfmEEpbamdash Met OfficeJuly , Wednesday could reach Cin the East and South East ndash equalling this yearrsquos record high which was set at Heathrow and Northolt on June .The hottest July day on record is .Cndash a record which looks unlikely to be beaten next week.Mr Burkill said: ldquoTherersquos a risk of some thundery showers developing through the rest of the week, therersquos a bit of uncertainty.ldquoWe could see some wet weather coming in from the west so things could turn a bit fresher, or the hot and sunny weather could continue.ldquoBut it doesnrsquot look like temperatures will get much hotter than C .He added: ldquoThe hot weather could last through much of the next week and into next weekend or it could break down much earlier ndash therersquos a lot to play for.

title: kevin-mackenna-glasgow-39-s-miles-worse-time-snp-can-39-t-blame-tories
story: And yet it must be true, mustnrsquot it  All those lestyle surveys telling us that wersquore the friendliest, rock n roll city on the planet: best for nightle top for student experience best UK retail emporiums outside of London cool restaurants around every corner and some of them vegan too. And look at Finnieston. Not long ago there was tumbleweed and empty golden Virginia packets blowing through the place now you canrsquot get moving for hipsters and halloumi.The honeyed encomiums of the consultants drip with per-diem optimism. According to Invest Glasgow, the cityrsquos inward investment team, ldquoGlasgow is at the centre of one the UKrsquos largest and most successful city regions. Scotlandrsquos largest city and only metropolitan region generated pound.billion GVA in . Last week this city found itself near the top of another cheeriness poll. This one surveyed the UKrsquos happiest places to live and work. Presumably, respondents all had a job and a roof over their heads.Even in the most jocund fun factories there always lurks a wandering Jeremiah. Earlier this month, Gary Smith, secretary of the GMB Union in Scotland, expressed a rather less ecstatic tone. In an interview in The Herald on Sunday he said: ldquoIt feels like a city that is in decline. Wersquove got public buildings in a state of decay ndash the Mitchell Library, the problems with the Peoplersquos Palace ndash the streets are absolutely filthy and wersquove got an epidemic of rats in large parts of the city. Too often the politicians are happy to hide behind this bluff and bluster about lsquopeople make Glasgowrsquo. The people of Glasgow deserve better than they are getting.Mr Smith cited public spending cuts and stealth privatisation as factors in many of Glasgowrsquos challenges. ldquoAll of this leaves the city in a state that feels unkempt, unloved and, in a lot of areas, actually really filthy. It is a city that is in economic and political decline.Those of us who have spent most of our lives living and working in Glasgow know which version of Glasgow is the authentic one. Lestyle surveys never extend to the sprawling neighbourhoods that lie to the north and east of the city. In these places multi-deprivation and health inequality remain among the worst in Europe, as they have been for more than a century. Many of Mr Smithrsquos union members live in these places. Until now the social challenges faced by these communities could be camouflaged in the breathless optimism of economic brochures selling an inward investment Xanadu to their fabled blue-chip companies.If they are proclaiming more than , businessesare located in the Glasgow city region and that they support more than , jobsthen they inadvertently paint a bleak picture. Why do so many Glaswegian families remain locked out of this economic Klondyke  No matter how spectacular a cityrsquos economic growth might be no matter how optimistic its long-term projections, these are shallow and meaninglesstens of thousands of people in the same old communities are unable to share in the bounty. Real growth and not this sham facsimile of it would trickle down into these places instead of accumulating in the bank accounts of the same few.Affluence and success can make you blind to the fact that Glaswegian men can lose  years of their le expectancy on a seven-mile stretch of the M from east to west. But when backdoor privatisation results in truncated essential services and a non-union workforce, the signs of decline begin to encroach on the city centre and the leafier neighbourhoods. Ultimately, tenants will pay more for additional services like bin collections. Rather than investing in these services they outsource to private firms, the least of whose concerns is the welfare of their workers and the cost to tenants. This is always how privatisation works.Meanwhile, the meter on Glasgowrsquos equal pay scandal is still running. The entire fabric of the city has been mortgaged to meet the bill, but this extends only to . The city will have to find more cash to pay those women who have been working since then at an unequal rate.Meanwhile, the sht and concentration of economic and political power to boutique Edinburgh continues. What sort of country permits a much smaller city to operate twice as many flights and trains to London as the larger one in terms of population and business  Why does Glasgow Airport, which still resembles a brick port-a-cabin in places, still lack a rail link We learned too this week that Scotland has now become the worst country for drug deaths. This must surely be fake news. How can this be so when Glasgow, its biggest city, is so happy and cheery and friendly all the time  As surely as a broken tumbler follows a dirty look, the supporters of the Scottish Government blamed the Tories for not giving them the powers to address this. The worst rates of drug addiction are in Scotlandrsquos poorest neighbourhoods and form part of the pattern of deprivation and disadvantage in these places. We have devolved power in this area. You canrsquot begin to deal with drugs until you first address the chronic health inequalities in these communities.Scotlandrsquos future economic prosperity rests on the performance of its biggest and most important city. Glasgow needs a political, cultural and economic champion at the heart of government but you wonrsquot find it in this Scottish cabinet.

title: iran-diplomat-summoned-oil-tanker-seizure
story: The Foreign Secretary, speaking after a meeting of the Governmentrsquos emergency committee Cobra, said the vessel was seized in Omani waters in ldquoclear contravention of international law.He told reporters inside the Foreign and Commonwealth Office that, having spoken to his Iranian counterpart Mohammad Javad Zar, Tehran saw the situation as a ldquotit for tat following the detention of Grace  in Gibraltar.Govt emergency cttee COBR met again this pm.Reaffirmed UK desire to de-escalate but confirmed Stena Impero was seized in OMANI waters in clear contravention of international law  discussed how  secure safety of UK int shipping in Straits of Hormuz. Parliament  be updated Monmdash Jeremy HuntJuly , ldquoNothing could be further from the truth, he said.ldquoGrace  was detained legally in Gibraltarian waters because it was carrying oil, against EU sanctions, to Syria, and thatrsquos why the Gibraltarian authorities acted totally with respect to due process and totally within the law.ldquoStena Impero was seized in Omani waters in clear contravention of international law, it was then forced to sail into Iran.ldquoThis is totally and utterly unacceptable. It raises very serious questions about the security of British shipping, and indeed international shipping, in the Strait of Hormuz.Mr Hunt said MPs would be updated about what ldquofurther measures the Government will take, on Monday, adding that the threat level had been raised to three.ldquoOur priority continues to be to find a way to de-escalate the situation.ldquoThatrsquos why I reached flagged vessel reversed, we need that ship released, and we continue to be very concerned about the safety and welfare of the  crew members.The Foreign Office earlier summoned the Iranian charge drsquoaffaires, Mohsen Omidzamani, following the incident.Iran has directly linked the seizure of the vessel with Britainrsquos role in detaining a tanker carrying Iranian oil earlier this month.A spokesman for IranrsquosCouncil was quoted as saying ldquothe rule of reciprocal action is well known in international law and that Tehran made the right decision in the face of an ldquoillegitimate economic war and seizure of oil tankers.The explanation, which contrasts with a suggestion on Friday night that the Stena Impero was ldquoviolating international maritime rules and had collided with a fishing boat, came as the UK Government warned British ships to stay away from the Strait of Hormuz.Iranian TV showed balaclava-clad commandos boarding the tanker from a helicopter.HMS Montrose, which is patrolling the Persian Gulf to protect shipping, and earlier this month intercepted Iranian patrol boats surrounding another UK-flagged tanker, reportedly arrived minutes too late to prevent the latest incident.Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt described the incident as a ldquohostile act and told Sky News the frigate was  minutes away from being able to help.Stena Bulk, which owns the Stena Impero, said the ship was in ldquofull compliance with all navigation and international regulations when it was seized by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard.A second oil tanker, the Liberian-flagged Mesdar, which is managed by Norbulk Shipping UK, veered off course towards the Iranian coast after it was boarded by armed guards at about .pm on Friday.The Mesdarrsquos Glasgow-based operator said communication had since been re-established with the ship and the crew were unharmed. The tanker was reportedly allowed to resume navigation.Downing Street said Prime Minister Theresa May was in her constituency but was being kept informed of developments.Former chief of defence staff Lord Richards said Britain was ldquopretty limited in what military action it could take without the support of allies such as America, should economic sanctions fail to resolve the situation.But Mr Hunt said he had spoken to US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo about the situation, and President Donald Trump said the US would be ldquoworking with the UK.The Foreign Secretary said the US had a ldquodferent approach to dealing with Iran, and that the UK would continue to support the Iran nuclear deal.ldquoThis is about the safety and security of British and international shipping in one of the most important seaways in the world, and that is why wersquore calling on Iran to reverse this illegal act, he said.ldquoWersquore looking for ways to de-escalate the situation but wersquore also very clear that we will do what it takes to ensure the safety and security of British and international shipping.France and Germany joined condemnation of Iranrsquos actions, which have triggered concerns that it will lead to further oil price hikes amid heightened tensions in the Gulf involving Iran, the US and UK.Fears had been growing that the Iranian authorities were trying to seize a UK ship in retaliation for the seizure of the Grace  tanker off the coast of Gibraltar on July  in an operation involving Royal Marines.The Grace  was suspected of violating EU sanctions by carrying a cargo of Iranian oil destined for Syria in breach of sanctions and Mr Hunt later offered to help release the vesselIran guaranteed it would not breach sanctions imposed on Bashar Assadrsquos regime.But Iranrsquos supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called the tankerrsquos seizure an act of ldquopiracy on Tuesday and warned the UK to expect a response.A statement from Stena Bulk said ship manager Northern Marine Management had lost contact with the crew of  after ldquounidentied small crafts and a helicopter approached the vessel at about pm on Friday.

title: new-laws-clamp-workplace-gagging-clauses
story: In recent months, legislators have come under pressure to protect victims of workplace abuse from being silenced by bosses after a number of high-profile cases.Last year, Sir Philip Green was accused of using non-disclosure agreementsto stop several former employees from speaking out about bullying and sexual harassment at his Arcadia retail group.Many businesses use NDAs to protect commercially-sensitive information but company bosses have come under scrutiny for their alleged use of the clauses in response to abuse allegations following the ldquome too movement.Business Minister Kelly Tolhurst has said that the government is now launching new laws to protect workers from their employerrsquos NDAs to hide potential abuse and discrimination.She said the Government will not tolerate the use of the confidentiality clauses to ldquosilence and intimidate victims to stop them speaking out.The new legislation is intended to, for the first time, ban NDAs from being used to stop people disclosing information to the police, doctors or lawyers.Currently, NDAs cannot prevent people from whistleblowing in the public interest.The crackdown will ensure that employers make clear the limitations of the confidentiality clause in plain English, the business minister said.It will also provide more advice to iniduals over the clauses and introduce new enforcement measures to deal with agreements which fail to meet the legal requirements.Ms Tolhurst said: ldquoThe vast majority of businesses comply with the law and use NDAs legitimately ndash from protecting commercially-sensitive information to preventing information being shared with competitors.ldquoAs we have seen in the news recently, there are a handful of employers using NDAs to cover up criminal acts in the workplace, including sexual harassment, assault and racist discrimination.ldquoThe new legislation will stamp out misuse, tackle unacceptable workplace cultures, protect iniduals and create a level playing field for businesses that comply with the law.Rebecca Hilsenrath, chief executive of the Equality  Human Rights Commission, said: ldquoHarassment and discrimination should never go unanswered and unchallenged just because victims are prevented from speaking out.ldquoThis new legislation will help to end ambiguity about employeesrsquo rights and stop the misuse of NDAs to protect corporate and personal reputations and obstruct justice.

title: 1m-campaign-keep-notebooks-charles-darwin-s-mentor-uk
story: The  notebooks written by Scottish geologist Sir Charles Lyell are currently in private hands but a campaign led by the University of Edinburgh needs to raise nearly pound million to buy the ldquofundamentally important archive.Contained within the notebooks are copies of correspondence with Darwin, who wrote in his autobiography: ldquoThe science of geology is enormously indebted to Lyell ndash more so, as I believe, than to any other man who ever lived.Lyell, who died in  aged , mentored Darwin after the latter ed from his five-year voyage on the Beagle in  and is credited with providing the scientic framework that helped Darwin develop his evolutionary theories.The works also feature the Victorian scientistrsquos perspective on issues of current concern, including climate change and threats to species ersity, as well as exploring the meaning of so-called deep time ndash the concept of geological time first described by a fellow Scot, James Hutton, in the th century.A government export ban was placed upon the historical notebooks in a bid to keep them in the UK, giving campaigners until July  to raise the pound, needed to purchase the collection.However, with pound, raised by pledges from more than  supporters ranging from the Geological Society of London to science broadcasters and writers Nicholas Crane, Hermione Cockburn and Richard Fortey, the export bar has been extended by three months in the hope of reaching the target amount.If the campaign is successful, the University of Edinburgh has pledged to make the collection freely available to the public.Jeremy Upton, the universityrsquos library and collections director, said: ldquoThe prospect of acquiring and making freely accessible such a fundamentally important archive collection as Sir Charles Lyellrsquos notebooks is a thrilling one.Professor James A Secord, from the University of Cambridge and director of the Darwin Correspondence Project, said: ldquoThe notebooks are key to appreciating his standing as arguably the most signicant figure in the earth sciences in Britain in the past two centuries.#OTD in , Sir Charles Lyell was born so today would have been his nd birthday! He is best known as the author of Principles of Geology, that presented unormitarianisn, stating that the Earth was shaped by the same processes still operating today. #RockStar pic ozTqhGVhbsmdash British Geological SurveyNovember , President of Edinburgh Geological Society Robert Gatlf described the ldquocolossal impact of Lyell on geology.ldquoLyell was one the first geologists to bring the subject to public attention, he said.ldquoOne of the key things that he recognised was that we can use the current environment and natural processes as the key to the past history of the earth.ldquoHis notebooks are so important to the development of geological thinking in Britain, it would be a travesty to see them lost so this fundraising campaign is crucial.

title: lib-dems-urge-new-spfl-board-publish-secret-report-football-sectarianism
story: The new SPFL board is set to be appointed at the annual general meeting on Monday and Scottish Liberal Democrat justice spokesman Liam McArthur has demanded it makes the data public.A joint investigation by the party and anti-sectarian charity Nil By Mouth found last month that the SPFL has created a list of unacceptable behaviour, including sectarian incidents, at football grounds covering almost two years.To be able to view the data, the Scottish Government signed a contract banning it from publishing the information.Holyrood committee: secret sectarianism report must be publishedMr McArthur said: "The first item on the agenda for the new SPFL board should be to agree to publish in full the information it has secretly collected on instances of sectarian abuse at games over the last two years."If it does not, any claims by the board about its determination to kick sectarianism out of football will lack credibility."Sectarian behaviour at football matches continues to tarnish the sports reputation and spoils the game for the vast majority of well-behaved fans. Theres no place for it in st century Scotland."This data needs to be out in the openwere genuinely to have a chance at opening up public debate and stamping out unacceptable behaviour."The new board has the opportunity to immediately right this wrong."He criticised the Scottish Government for signing up to the deal.: No need to define sectarianism in Scottish hate crime laws, surveyThe Scottish Government has urged the SPFL to make the data available, which SPFL chief executive Neil Doncaster previously said would be discussed by the board.A Scottish Government spokesman said: "Our strong preference has always been that the SPFL should make the data publicly available - and we have made that point consistently to them."

title: calls to reinstate 325 bus route via dyce
story: North-east MSP Mark McDonald and local councillor, Martin Ford, have both acted upon the pleas of residents to reinstate the  bus service to its original route via ASDA and Dyce Health Centre.Since the change of route, the bus travels through Dyce via Victoria Street instead of to Dyce ASDA, which is near the Health Centre in Altonrae Gardens.Mr McDonald and Mr Ford have both written to Stagecoach Managing Director, Andrew Jarvis asking that the old route be reinstated. Commenting, Mr McDonald said: “I have written to Andrew Jarvis, Managing Director at Stagecoach Bluebird to advise him of the challenges my constituents face with the review of this service. It is essential that public transport is available for patients to get to the health centre in Dyce, and this service must be reinstated as soon as possible.“I urge Stagecoach to review this decision in order that a transport link is in place for those needing access to local healthcare”.The residents of Newmachar also have local councillor Martin Ford on their side.Cllr Ford first wrote to Stagecoach Bluebird in October asking the company to reconsider its decision to cease running buses via Dyce Asda.The bus stop at Asda is very close to Dyce Health Centre in Altonrae Gardens so many Newmachar residents used the buses via Asda to visit their doctor and dentist.The change in bus routing in Dyce was discussed at the October meeting of New Machar Community Council, and again at last week’s meeting. On both occasions, concerned residents were in attendance. At the November meeting, Mr William Manius, operations director with Stagecoach Bluebird, also attended, at the Community Council’s request.As well as inidual letters of complaint to Stagecoach Bluebird, a petition has been signed by nearly  people unhappy at the route change. Stagecoach Bluebird have now said they will review the requests received for buses via Dyce Asda and look at use patterns.Meanwhile, Cllr Ford has written again to Stagecoach Bluebird managing director Andrew Jarvis.In his letter to Mr Jarvis, Cllr Ford says: “Taking all the representations made into account, I hope Stagecoach Bluebird will agree to find a way to again provide direct bus services for Newmachar residents to and from Dyce Asda shopping centre.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Forget Neil and Buzz, meet Scotland’s coosmonaut BuzzBò! viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Commenting, Cllr Ford said: “The buses via Asda provided an important service for Newmachar residents needing to access health and other facilities.”Cllr Ford has also written to Bains Coaches who operate a limited service between Oldmeldrum, Newmachar and Aberdeen to seethey will route some of their buses via Dyce ASDA.

The name derives from Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on the Moon, and the Gaelic word for cow, Bò.Alex Keen, launch specialist from Sent into Space, said: “Launching at Gilnockie Tower was a real treat. Not only were the team from VisitScotland a great bunch to work with but the countryside we crossed in pursuit of our payload is one of the most beautul and dramatic landscapes we’ve visited. “Once the Coosmonaut was back in our hands, we were genuinely sad to leave and head back to England.”A new tourism map highlighting Scotland’s links to space exploration and the first moonwalk has also been released.On the new trail...among the Scottish landmarks on the new VisitScotland map is the dark sky observatory in Dalmellington, Ayrshire.The Scotland is Out of this World trail is part of the new VisitScotland campaign of the same name.The trail features Scottish connections to each planet in the solar system, as well as fun facts and details of science centres and the best places to
